title: Reflexive Pronouns
summary: This lesson explains how and when to use reflexive pronouns such as 'myself', 'yourself', 'himself', etc., including emphasis, preposition use, and reciprocal pronouns like 'each other' and 'one another'. It also covers common mistakes with reflexive forms and the expressions 'by myself' and 'on my own'.
content: Reflexive pronouns are: myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves.
Use reflexive pronouns when the subject and object of the sentence are the same.
Reflexive pronouns can follow prepositions when referring back to the subject.
Use reflexive pronouns for emphasis to show that the subject did the action personally.
Some verbs that are reflexive in other languages are not reflexive in English, such as wash, shave, dress, hurry, and relax.
Use 'by myself', 'by yourself', etc., to mean alone or without help.
You can also use 'on my own', 'on your own', etc., with similar meaning.
Reciprocal pronouns 'each other' and 'one another' are used when two or more people do the same action to each other.

examples.rule: Use reflexive pronouns when the subject and object are the same.
examples: She cut herself chopping the onions.
We really enjoyed ourselves at the party.
Talking to oneself is not necessarily a sign of madness.

examples.rule: Use reflexive pronouns after prepositions referring to the subject.
examples: He should be really proud of himself.
With the 3-D printer and this scanner, you can print a small version of yourself.

examples.rule: Use reflexive pronouns to emphasise who did the action.
examples: I will talk to Anna myself.
I think you should do it yourself instead of having it done.

examples.rule: Do not use reflexive pronouns with common non-reflexive verbs in English.
examples: The first thing I do is wash, shave, and dress.
When I arrive home, I only want to relax on the sofa.
Please hurry, or we’ll be late.
The door opened, and everybody got in.

examples.rule: Use 'by myself' or 'on my own' to mean alone or without help.
examples: My son doesn’t like to be by himself; he always wants us around.
She raised her four children by herself.
I was on my own all morning.
She did it on her own.

examples.rule: Use reciprocal pronouns to show mutual action between people.
examples: When the twins found each other, they had been living apart for more than ten years.
You should try to understand one another.

tips: Reflexive pronouns are used when the subject and object are the same.
Use 'by yourself', 'by myself', etc., to mean alone or without help.
Don't use reflexive pronouns with verbs like 'wash', 'dress', or 'relax' unless absolutely necessary.
Use reflexive pronouns for emphasis to highlight who performed the action.
‘Each other’ and ‘one another’ are reciprocal, not reflexive – don’t confuse them.
'On my own' and 'by myself' have similar meanings and can be used interchangeably.
